Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Political Economy of Extractive Industries Conflicts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

Extractive industries conflicts are an increasingly common and costly phenomenon in the world today, particularly in developing countries. This project investigates why violent conflict continues to occur in extractive industries, particularly in Latin America, and tests several interventions designed to reduce the level of conflict around mining through improved responsiveness to local communities and reduced capture by government officials. The PI identifies three sub-national mechanisms that may explain extractive industries conflict: (1) asymmetric information, (2) commitment problems, and (3) capture by elected officials. The co-PI then test each of these mechanisms through three randomized field experiments in Peru that include private sector, NGO and government partners. The PI test whether improved responsiveness by policymakers and the private sector can reduce conflict in extractive sectors.


Technical Summary

While previous studies in the social sciences have identified a relationship between natural resources and conflict at the macro (cross-national) level, this project focuses on micro-level mechanisms in Latin America. The PI identifies three sub-national mechanisms that explain why conflicts occur around extractive industries: 1) Asymmetric information, 2) Commitment problems and 3) Capture by elected officials. The PI tests each of the mechanisms through three randomized field experiments in Peru that include private sector, NGO and government partners. This project examines sub-national mechanisms for resource conflicts other than civil war, such as labor conflicts, environmental conflicts, and populist rural uprisings that are short of armed insurrection. The use of the randomized field experimental techniques allows the PI to be more confident that the effects found are indeed causal effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mining conflicts continue to be a major problem in the developing world, with about three quarters of developing countries experiencing riots and/or protests related to extractive industries during 2013-2015. To address this, governments and international organizations are increasing turning to third party mediation processes to resolving conflicts. The UN Security Council has endorsed this approach, saying that ``one of the most promising approaches to the peaceful settlement of disputes is skillful third-party mediation,” that can expected to do no less than `` resolve conflicts constructively rather than destructively and … save succeeding generations from the scourge of war" (United Nations Security Council 2009).

Since 2012, the ONDS (Oficina Nacional de Dialogo y Sostenibilidad) has implemented conflicts resolution workshops, known as “mesas de dialogo” (round tables), with the goal of reducing social conflicts related to mining. The roundtables aim to solve the conflicts through dialogue involving local leaders, government, civil society and mining companies[1]. To understand how the mesas de dialogo have been functioning in Peru since their inception, we have carried out a survey of participants in more than 20 mesas de dialogo from across the country.

Participants were selected from four sectors: government, civil society, mining, firms, and local leaders, and sampled from 67 dialogues tables that took place between 2012 and 2016. The sampling survey implemented was constructed by first identifying the universe of conflict cases related to mining, oil and gas from the Willaqniki reports – monthly reports summarizing mesas de dialogos’ status) – and sub setting the cases where ONDS was identified as having directly participated. In 66 of those cases, 336 potential or reported participants could be identified using secondary source material, including searches of public officials in the related districts, information sourced directly from the ONDs regarding participation or other public government sources. Using email and telephone contact information collected at the time of the mesa de dialogo, enumerators successfully carried out interviews with 66 of the 336 participants, coming from a total of 26 cases. It was found that contact information for many of the earlier mesas de dialogo was out of date and thus not usable (particularly those from 2014), and that in some cases the mesa process was held in only a cursory fashion.

From our interviews we learned that for a ten percent increase in municipal budget execution in the pre-mediation period the probability of conflict being resolved rises 14 percentage points and reduced tensions are 21 percent more likely. When international commodities rise by a standard deviation, however, the probability of a mediation table resolving a conflict drops by 33 percentage points, and the likelihood of conflict restarting rises 56 percentage points. In addition, we learn that both strong government performance and high prices greatly reduce participants' satisfaction with the mesa de dialogo process. At the same time, better government performance increases the probability that respondents report that mesas de dialogo generate trust between the participants. Finally, higher commodity prices are associated with a major reduction in confidence in the dialogue tables' ability to reduce conflict.

The results of this study suggest that institutional factors, rather than the skillfulness of mediators, are fundamental to the success of mediation efforts. The evidence points to building government capacity to efficiently manage the costs and benefits of extractive industries. These results indicate that high capacity government can prevent conflict by efficiently responding to changing conditions, as well as help resolve conflict even when it does emerge. This comes in contrast to alternative explanations that suggest that personalities, mediator expertise or other qualitative factors are decisive in resolving conflict.
